label: Letter 1 from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, May 26, 1943
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding a baseball game to raise money for war bonds she had attended, her life in Washington, and the problem she is going to have replacing the typists in her office. Gertrude continues in her letter to discuss possibilities of joining Sidney in Hawaii if she takes a job in the Women’s Army Auxiliary Corps (WAACs) and the cottage at Watch Hill she has rented for the children’s summer.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
May 26th '43
Dear Sidney,
My trip to the Ball Game with the Dills and Field
Marshall Sir Archibald Wavell was great fun. He had never seen
baseball before and everyone explained it to him from all sides.
Kate Smith sang over the microphone, Babe Ruth made a speach for
war bonds, Bing Crosby cruned and Wavell was made to take a bow. He got
more applause than all the other stars put together and had to
walk out on the field and say a few words over the microphone. We
sat in the box with Knox and Baruch and the seats were incidently
$1000 war bond seats. A gift of the Washington Post- Mr Eugene Mayer.
The game made two million dollars in bonds that night. It was
quite a show and I enjoyed the whole spaectacle. Mrs Mark Clark was
in the party,and a sprinkling of aides to hold off the autograph
seekers that swarmed about.
Yesterday afternoon Tony Frissell and I went to the
Dills at tea time to take some photos of the Big Shots. They were
so sweet about it, and we laughed alot as we exploded bulbs in their
faces. We told them it was for posterity for all our albums. They
will not be used publicly of course. I think the whole mission must be
pretty tired for they have had conferences from morning to night[,]and whe[n]
they get all through they have to be interviewed by newspaper men from
45 states who are waiting to fire questions. However to my surprise they
all seem to think the Washington climate is fine. I guess thats polite
talk,or else its fine by comparison to India.
I was awake last night at 2 A.M. and thought about you
just about ready for bed at nine o'clock your time. My how I wish
I were with you darling. Its the old theme. you will be so used to your
bachlor life and living apart,I wonder howyou will feel when the day
finally arrives and we are again united. Time marches on[,]and I only 
wish it would go faster so we could get this war over with. It
stretches on and on like groping through a long dark corridor and
never getting to the end of it.
I wonder if you had a nice Sunday on the beach and if
Duke Konimoko was out on his board riding the waves like a panther.
It is always too late to get tennis after working hours so I have not
played at all since last year. To and from the office is my only
breath of air and exercise. Gasolene has completly stopped. No taxi's
-few busses[,]and all the gas ta[n]ks dry. I see no hope of Chevey Chase
even on Sunday.
I am getting an other recruit into my office[not till July]
but even that will help. A girl called KatyLou Crunden I went to school
with twenty three years ago[,]and have not seen since. Miss Charlotte got
her for me and she is a peach. That is real luck. My pal Miss Fearson
is leaving for the west coast the end of June and is taking the other
typist with her, This makes matters very tough and they will be hard to
replace. There just are no good girls anymore.
[End Page 1]
2
Does the Navy out there use Waves for typists and clerical
not the way they do in the Navy Department?
There is a terrific shortage of WAACS and WAVES in all branches
and recruiting is not any too successful_to date- so I am told.
I cant resign and join the WAACS,and if Idid I would probably end
baking bread in Texas. I am in hopes I shall get to the Pacific
in time with this outfit as I think there is a pretty good chance
something will develop along those lines. I am going to work on
that possability. Its too late now to be interested in the other
direction- thats the way I feel any how.
Its the most beautiful day out to-day. It rained torrents
all night so the air is clear and the sun is shining and I wish
I were in the country under the trees.
I wonder how Morris is getting on. I hope O.K. now.
I have taken a cottage at Watch Hill-for the children so Honey
can go too. I got a house with 4 bedrooms and two baths and a maids
room. A lawn, etc.Its sounds fine and only costs $900 for the
season. I think they will be much happier and I shall try and
persuade Candice to go up and cook for them.
I got my air conditioner insat[a]lled by a fluke of luck.
We telephoned every company in town.They a l said "impossible,too
busy" One day two men came to the house- said they had come to
install airconditioners, Rose put them to work,when theywere all
through and took the address down they realized they had worked
all day at the wrong house. Rose had a good laugh and they did
too. We might have waited all summer for them, now someone else
will be the unlucky ones. Pretty funny! and typical of life in
Washington.
Do you get a stiff neck and a stiff back from sitting
down all day? I feel so stiff and ache all over.My fanny is getting
as big as Nanny Tiffany's,and I shall waddle stiffly as I walk
waddle to meet that incomming plane at the end of the war when
you came back to the U.S.A.
I dream about cables and numbers, and paper work all night
and wonder if you do too. Maybe it cdmes from lack of exercise
which really does relax one- I dont know, but I find sleaping 
very jumpy these days.
Enjoy that blue water for me and make an extra splash
under the waves when you think of Washington,and the Q Bldg,and
Constitution Ave.
All my love to you sweetheart. Take care of yourself
and try not to forget [y]our Gertie who loves you very much.
Always-
Gertie.
[End Page 2]
